paper_abstract: The Banach fixed-point theorem states that a contraction mapping on a complete metric space has a unique fixed point. Given an oracle access to a finite metric space (M, d) and a contraction mapping f : M -> M on it, we show that the fixed point off can be found with an expected O(root vertical bar M vertical bar) oracle queries. We also show that every randomized algorithm for finding a fixed point must make an expected Omega(root vertical bar M vertical bar) oracle queries to (M, d) and f for some finite metric space (M, d) and some contraction mapping f : M -> M on it. As a generalization of the Banach fixed-point theorem, the Caristi-Kirk fixed-point theorem gives weaker conditions on (M. d) and f guaranteeing the existence of a fixed point off. We show that every randomized algorithm that finds a fixed point must make the expected Omega(vertical bar M vertical bar) oracle queries to (M. d) and f for some finite metric space (M, d) and some function f : M -> M satisfying the conditions of the Caristi-Kirk fixed-point theorem. paper_title: Optimal bounds on finding fixed points of contraction mappings
